comments.commentBody: In this hemisphere it's: "Oy, vey..."
Oh.  Joy.
The Trump cure for the Bush illness could well do away with the body politic.
One dynasty down...one to go! :)
We should thank Trump for preventing what could have been a true failure of American democracy:Bush vs Clinton

comments.userDisplayName: Divorce is Good For American Economy
comments.commentBody:
Agreed.

The establishment with its $130+ mil in fellow average Americans insulting ways bet on Jeff Bush, similar money bet on Hillary Clinton (the Dem version of establishment's candidate) are rightfully afraid that in these elections it might indeed be not so easy to fool enough Americans.

Trump will, of cause, while at the White House, do not intend to implement all of the on-the-trail made statements but he will be, also as a centrist, effective enough catalyst for some much needed, while not revolutionary changes, for change benefiting average Americans.

And I will bet that political correctness will, thanks to his presidential bully pulpit, be put on defensive, where it belongs.

Hillary Clinton is part of the Establishment and that is why Trump will win the election in November. People in both parties are sick and tired of the corrupt politics in this country. Now that Bernie Sanders is out, the Democrats have no Anti-Establishment candidate. By the way, 33 of the unbound Pennsylvania delegates have said tonight they will vote for Trump so he will get the 1237 he needs for the nomination.
Why would anyone repeat anything after you?  Your understanding is as shallow as a puddle in a parking lot.

Let me saying something to provoke some thinking in this NY Times echo box.

Republican voters are further along on the curve than Democrats. The key message of the past 4-8 years is that the establishment/ status quo has no interest in the welfare of the common folk. The mainstream media/ lobbyists all prop up this corrupt system, and to that end, there's absolutely no difference in the "Centrist" wing of both parties. Clinton/ Bush all the same!

Republicans base voters who are less affluent got impacted earlier, and hence the middle finger to the mainstream Republican party as early as 2008-2010.

Democrats are just waking up, and hence the Bernie support base. Although some of it started to show up in 2012 in the Occupy Wall Street movement.

Repeat after me: Hillary is part of the problem, not the solution!

Remember the trolls, before you draw any conclusions from the number of comments saying the same thing and, even more, the number of Recommends on the Most Recommended comments. I say that purposely without reading comments but knowing how articles such as this one, articles which seemingly "interpret" events, draw the trolls.

'Winners are decided in a democracy by election results not polling'

Nope, winners are decided by the Electoral College. Your vote can be set aside as the Super Delegates will toe the party line, not listen to the voters.

@Said Ordaz

The Electoral College has nothing to do with the primaries. And in this contest, Clinton is well ahead of Sanders WITHOUT the super delegates precisely because more than 3 million people have chosen her over Sanders. Democratic voters have been resoundingly clear about who they want as their nominee.

Scorecard is Hilary 12 million votes leading Bernie by 3.1 million votes who only has 8.8 million votes.  Winners are decided in a democracy by election results not polling.  Bernie's campaign to overturn election results by having superdelegates support him on the basis of polling and the demographics of his votes in the primary (more Republicans, independents and younger Democrats) is undemocratic and in reality race based as Bernie's supporters are overwhelmingly white which means Bernie wants to overturn the will of the overwhelming Black majority (along with majority Hispanics and middle/older age whites) who voted for Hilary. Time for Bernie and his Bros. to show they are strong enough to support a strong woman who will win the Presidency.
Your so-called Hillary quote is your own fantasy. Hillary would never say those words.

As a strong supporter of Senator Sanders' candidacy, this message is both offensive to me and, at the same time, very true. It's offensive in that it denigrates Sanders supporters who have been extremely active and involved in supporting the campaign thus far. It chooses to interpret a vision for 2020 as meaning we're going to sit around doing nothing in the meantime.

The message has been clear from the onset that Bernie Sanders (and no one else, for that matter) cannot accomplish much alone. We need to also ensure those we elect to the open Congressional seats and to our state houses and state legislatures also support the progressive agenda. We must keep a strong focus and level of commitment and action to ensure our progressive ideals are not lost and not watered down by a DNC establishment White House. To highlight the urgent need to keep the pressure on and the activism high we need only look back at the result of the last mid-term elections and the pathetic situation in many of the states governments (like Maine). So, in this respect, I agree with your post. But, don't characterize us as lazy.

Nasty. That is not going to help.
The green party will do well this year. That is where many Bernie supporters will go, if their change to vote Bernie Sanders is being taken away by a corrupt rigged system and media blackouts. That are not excuses, but facts.

That work may involve building a new party, pulling in progressives and independents. If you hoped to have these people work within the Democratic party, you ought to use persuasion instead of insult.

It amazes how lazy so many of Bernie Sanders supporters happen to be.

So, your hero is likely not going to get the nomination and your answer is we will come back again in 2020 to fight again.

Excuse me, but did you not happen to notice we have other people to elect in this country other than the president and progressive causes to fight for on every level of government, every day?

So, do not even think for a New York minute you are serious about for progressive causes if you take the lazy way out and choose do nothing other than hibernate in the comfort of your home for the next four years.

Is this simple enough for you all you "progressive" Sanders worshippers out there?

You have work to do, so do it!

Israel,

They are in the same party, fighting for the same issues and there is only so much time and resources to win in November. Ever bad thing Sanders says about hillary or about the democrats from this point on saves republicans money from having to say it too. They need to tear down Hillary and tear down democrats and Bernie should not be the author of those attacks. Bernie entered the nomination fight 10 months ago, had ten months to make his case and failed to do so, lost decisively to Hillary and should now turn his attention to defeating republicans in the fall.
Her platform and policy positions won. It isn't just she that won, but her ideas too won over his ideas. And while it seemed close at times over the past few month, in reality he has been beat soundly and spanked badly. And part of what he signed up for in pursuing the party nomination is joining in with the party nominee if he lost and helping her win,
Everything negative he says from this point on is a referendum on his personal character and whether he is a good and honest candidate. Every negative word will mean he loses respect within the party and loses influence long term with people he has served with.
Every time he refuses to start working for the party and Hillary forces Hillary to reduce his role in the convention in July, keep him from speaking there, from influencing the platform, from committee seats in congress after the election. He is either with the party or not.

It's an unbelievable uphill struggle to run as an independent in an entrenched two-party system!  The system is terribly corrupt right now.  I see no future for democracy or those holding office taking care of those in the middle class.  The country is being run by oligarchs.  Welcome to the new reality.   Hillary is part of this, in case you wonder.
And, he's not even a registered Democrat.  I need to find out how that works.  How do you get to run on the D ticket ?
So vote Trump?

Any Democrat can crush Donald Trump or any other GOP candidate, and become impossible to stop down ticket, too, by adopting the platform that Bernie Sanders is still competing to make the party's. Check out the last sentence of his 4/26/16 concession statement:

"I congratulate Secretary Clinton on her victories tonight, and I look forward to issue-oriented campaigns in the 14 contests to come.

I am proud that we were able to win a resounding victory tonight in Rhode Island, the one state with an open primary where independents had a say in the outcome. Democrats should recognize that the ticket with the best chance of winning this November must attract support from independents as well as Democrats. I am proud of my campaign’s record in that regard.

The people in every state in this country should have the right to determine who they want as president and what the agenda of the Democratic Party should be. That’s why we are in this race until the last vote is cast. That is why this campaign is going to the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia with as many delegates as possible to fight for a progressive party platform that calls for a $15 an hour minimum wage, an end to our disastrous trade policies, a Medicare-for-all health care system, breaking up Wall Street financial institutions, ending fracking in our country, making public colleges and universities tuition free and passing a carbon tax so we can effectively address the planetary crisis of climate change."

I  voted for Sanders, but I really enjoyed this editorial. Though I think Sanders himself has not done as much to fuel the conspiratorial rhetoric as Bruni implies, it has grown frustrating listening to dear friends speak of Clinton as though she is somehow new or distinctive in her deep links to monied interests and "establishment" politics. She's an imperfect candidate, but the frenzied animosity of too many Sanders supporters has lost all proportion with the real policy options presented to us in this election, to the point where some actually claim to look forward to a Trump presidency if only for the satisfaction of saying "I told you so." It's sad, and has planted the seeds of something akin to a Democratic Tea Party, equally divorced from reality or practical consequences.

I could venture an answer to your question. Establishments are allergic to change and nothing is more establishment than the NYTimes (unless it be the Clintons). It is quite incredible that Bernie has gotten as far as he has with all but a small corner of the media and its political, military, and corporate bed mates arrayed against him. And that tiny corner is only there thanks to the Internet.

According to XWordInfo, you have to go back to April 30, 1966 to find ANNUM clued in any other way than "Per ___", "Per ___ (yearly)", or "Per ___ (how budgets may be planned)".

In the 50-year-old puzzle, it was clued "Year: Lat.".

As for me, I don't know why it wasn't "ANNUS" crossing "SKIS".

Actually, I voted for Bernie. I like him a lot, but recently not so much, and some of you, if you are not Republicans, are going some very strange places.

I've spent the last decade pointing out facts to climate science deniers - unskeptical "skeptics" - and this is starting to sound very similar. The endless assertion that one is right and the facts are lying, for example. The refusal to look at sources outside one's comfort zone. I've gotten quite skilled at identifying the source of materials that dispute the truth.

No white knight can fix things if you don't vote down-ticket as well. If you could, did you bother to show up in 2014?

"None are adult men"
All transgender women (except genuine intersex people) ARE adult males! Men can't become women. It's a biological impossibility.
If a man wants to dress like a woman, that's fine. But he's still male. Womanhood isn't just frills and lipstick!
Per Mr. Rosenthal, when a man proclaims "I'm a woman", he becomes one. This reduces womanhood even further, to a mere feeling that a man has.
I flatly refuse to have the biological and political reality of my sex redefined in such a manner.
Transgender women choose to expose themselves to "abuse, bigotry and discrimination". They can take back their male privilege at any time by detransitioning.
Afraid of male violence? So are real women! And some of us don't want men to have carte blanche access to our private spaces. We don't have a detector that tells whether the obvious male in our change room is harmless or a dangerous creep.
Trans women are actually non-gender-conforming men. That's a hard thing to be. But they should get out there and fight their own battles against discrimination. (Just like the women's movement did!) Instead they reinforce gender conformity by colonizing womanhood.
You guys are male. You can't jump into the "woman box". So you need to break the "men box"! It will be hard. So were anti-slavery, woman suffrage and second wave feminism.
Meanwhile lobby for third gender/unisex spaces, if necessary for your safety. Don't use women's spaces to "validate" an impossible sex switch.

The primary impetus behind bathroom laws is sexual modesty, not fear of assault, but just because a man identifies as female does not remove the potential for sexual assault. Many people seem to assume that transgender women are simply females trapped in male bodies, but this isn’t true. Transgender people can be heterosexual, bisexual, gay or lesbians, but research conducted at the University of Minnesota ““suggests that the breakdown of sexualities among transsexual women—men who think of themselves as female--is 38% bisexual, 35% attracted to women, and 27% attracted to men.” This means that 73 percent of transgender women are sexually attracted to women and 35 percent are exclusively attracted exclusively to women. It doesn’t mean they necessarily want to have sex with women in public bathrooms, of course, but it is wrong to assume they posed no sexual assault threat.

@Sue
GreaT points Sue, couldn't agree more.
@Ray
Hmmm, I not convinced you're taking this seriously Ray. Your revealing comment presents as rather cartoonish, with said “behemoths” threatened by “ogling, giggling girls”.
If you wish to inform yourself about the consequences of a 6.3-foot 280-pound man in a dress who insists on using the women's facilities, read on…
http://www.sptimes.com/News/92599/Pasco/Cross_dressing_man_se.shtml
He appears @15:40mins in this pro-trans docu film;
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Yzy8oh5Fw0

The only discomfort I've ever noticed in the ladies room is not when a man comes in (that's usually a janitor, announced, to mop the floor or unclog the john). It's when there are very butch, masculine-looking "women" in there. You go in there and suddenly you wonder if you've entered the men's room. Significantly it's these male-looking females that have caused most of the fuss lately in NC. Perhaps there should be special restrooms for "women" who don't look female.

As a transgender woman, the bathroom bills which have been gaining prominence in several states reflect a lack of education of transgender people by cisgender individuals. Understanding the stigma, discrimination and outright bigotry may make others understand that this is not a choice, and sometimes at great risks to ourselves we attempt operations as we navigate the supposed gender binary.  Maybe understanding that gender is more on a continuum we can progress beyond bathrooms and discuss egalitarianism.

The title of your piece is offensive and your position,- if you don't think that there are people manipulating the system, is. . .well. . . .naïve.

27% of the registered voters in the state of New York, are not allowed to vote in the primaries. Who do you think the independent voters who were not allowed to vote last week would have supported?

I think Bernie is right to continue his campaign, although I also hope he doesn't continue attacking Hillary.

The point of pressing on is to make sure the political revolution that is required and that so many of us agree with will not just be lost or ignored. Mrs. Clinton ultimately should be grateful that Bernie led the way to public awareness of the terrible inequality and other issues that have been roiling underneath the mainstream media's notice.

And Bernie did say he wouldn't start a third party and thereby hand the presidency over to the Republicans like the Nader fiasco did. This is why he became a Democrat, not to just be an interloper, but to preserve the system by exposing the problems and staying around to help fix them, win or lose the highest office.

Extremism happens when one believes that the only acceptable reality is that he will be crowned as winner.  The consolation for the other non-Extremism winner is that although they both are in the same race, each occupies a different reality plane and thus can both be winners.
